Pioneer's Sheffield: No Free Market for Oil
Pioneer Natural Resources CEO Scott Sheffield has watched the boom-and-bust cycles of the oil industry for decades. When he saw that the coronavirus pandemic was choking demand and that Opec-plus was collapsing into a price war, he thought it could pose an existential threat to US oil companies. Sheffield’s solution was unprecedented in modern US history: persuade the Texas state government to help President Donald Trump negotiate with a producer group (OD Mar.31'20). In this exclusive interview with Energy Intelligence conducted on the eve of Friday's meeting of G20 energy ministers, Sheffield explains his proposal for temporary government intervention to save the US oil business.

Q: What is your view of the tentative Opec-plus deal to cut 10 billion barrels a day for two months, provided G20 countries -- and the US in particular -- commit to reducing an additional 5 million b/d?

A: We pretty much expected Russia especially would ask for US participation because we took away a lot of the market share. Since the Opec-plus agreement came together with Russia and Saudi [Arabia], the Permian [Basin] has grown from 2 million to 5 million b/d (IOD Apr.10'20). We wanted Texas to give the president a tool for the toolbox: If the largest producer in the US, which is Texas, could help get a deal together, then they could have that tool.

Q: What do you want the president to do from here?

A: The US has to figure out how to participate, and the president has to make sure the deal closes. He's a closer, and he needs to make sure the deal doesn't fall apart.

Q: Can the US trust Russia and Saudi Arabia?

A: Now, that's the problem, and it's why we're only recommending it conditioned for a few months. I would say until about August is the most critical time period to wait until demand starts coming back. I'm assuming that the shelter-in-place order will be lifted for most states at least by early to midsummer. We should see demand start coming back at that point in time. Hopefully, if the world is contributing 10 million to 15 million b/d of cuts, that will rebalance the inventories over the next several months. I don't think you could do much more. With the demand off about 20 million to 25 million b/d, it's a pretty good starting place.

Our key message to the [Texas] Railroad Commission and to the federal officials is to stabilize the price at around $30 a barrel versus going back to $10 or $15/bbl. I'm trying to keep that disaster case away. In a disaster case, you decimate our industry, you decimate our service companies, and you decimate our infrastructure. And a lot of it won't come back in a $10 oil price scenario.

replies.msg:
Q: How does $30 oil change US production?

A: I think it'll be $30 for the next 12 months, and then jump up to $40 after that. We will have taken contango out of the curve. It should bring down tanker rates, allow the US to export more. But I still think you're going to see US production roll over. It's probably not going to roll over till third or fourth quarter. It'll start declining and then decline going into the end of next year and we'll be somewhere between 10 million or 11 million b/d from our [recent output of] 13 million b/d by the end of next year. Because I don't think you'll see rigs start up until WTI [West Texas Intermediate] prices are in that $40-plus range. And we don't see that until 2023.


Q: Exxon Mobil, the American Petroleum Institute (API) and others like Marathon Oil, Ovintiv and Occidental oppose the Texas Railroad Commission (RRC) using its pro-rating authority (OD Apr.9'20). What's their agenda?

A: The majors have been very aggressive to shut down any compromise in regard to tariffs, import fees, blocking foreign oil. They have no solution. In my opinion, they'd rather the independents go bankrupt so they can buy them cheap. People have told me API should be renamed EPI instead of API for Exxon. Somebody told me they should rename TXOGA [Texas Oil and Gas Association], EXOGA.

The independents like Marathon and Ovintiv -- they use the words "free trade" when I've talked to both CEOs -- but there hasn't been free trade in oil in my entire career and there hasn't been free trade from 1929. It [was] pro-rated by the Texas Railroad Commission for about 40 years and it's been pro-rated by Opec for the last 60 years.

The real reason -- they can't admit it -- but if you look at the leverage of those two companies, they're way overleveraged. Some companies can't afford to take a 20% percent cut in their production. It could affect their credit, their balance sheet. This is just my opinion -- they have not discussed it -- but if you look at the leverage of those two companies, you see the leverage. Same with Oxy.

Q: What happens if Texas, via the Railroad Commission's pro-rating authority, limits production, but other states refuse to do so?

A: There's a group of producers trying to [convince the Oklahoma] commission. It wouldn't surprise me that if Texas does it, then Oklahoma would do it. too. North Dakota can't pro-rate, but they can do it in a different way. [Continental Resources Chairman] Harold Hamm thinks they can get up to a 10% reduction in North Dakota if they put on these stricter flaring [regulations], so you get the benefits of environmental stewardship by reducing flaring.

Q: How can you be sure that even limited pro-rating won't evolve into further government intervention?

A: Two or three CEOs I've talked to are worried about Opec continuing to ask us to participate. "If we participate once, will they ask again next year and the following year and the following year?" I'm totally against that. And when I testify at the [RRC hearing on Apr. 14], I want to make sure that this is a one-time event (OD Apr.7'20). They do it for a few months, and then hopefully they'll never do it again.

Deon Daugherty, Houston

墨西哥表示將與美國共同完成35萬桶日均原油減產額度
墨西哥總統洛佩斯10日説，美國同意增加原油減產以彌補墨西哥減產不足部分，雙方將共同完成日均減產35萬桶原油的額度。洛佩斯當天上午在新聞發佈會上表示，墨西哥承諾今年5至6月間將日均原油產量削減10萬桶，減至日均約168.6萬桶。他説，美國總統特朗普承諾美國將為墨西哥完成25萬桶減產額度。洛佩斯表示，希望相關舉措能提高國際原油價格，穩定經濟和市場。（新華社）

Apr. 10, 2020 10:25 PM ETThe United States Oil ETF, LP (USO)23 Comments
G-20 energy ministers failed today to devise a detailed plan to follow OPEC+ nations by cutting production to stop plunging oil prices caused by the Saudi-Russian price war and Covid-19.
OPEC+ had hoped the G-20 virtual meeting would produce a pledge for 4M bbl/day in cuts from the U.S., Canada, the U.K. and other producers not allied with the cartel, but the meeting ended with a press release that did not mention specific reduction targets and offered only to work together to ensure oil "market stability."
Some producers are pinning their hopes on Pres. Trump, who has been making frequent late-night phone calls to Russia's Pres. Putin, Saudi Arabia's King Salman and other key players in the oil market.
Earlier in the day, Mexican Pres. Lopez Obrador said Trump had promised him the U.S. would cover two-thirds of the production curbs OPEC+ had demanded of Mexico, although cartel officials have not announced any such deal.

quote.msg:
No oil market fix from today's G-20 meeting
Apr. 10, 2020 10:25 PM ETThe United States Oil ETF, LP (USO)23 Comments
G-20 energy ministers failed today to devise a detailed plan to follow OPEC+ nations by cutting production to stop plunging oil prices caused by the Saudi-Russian price war and Covid-19.
OPEC+ had hoped the G-20 virtual meeting would produce a pledge for 4M bbl/day in cuts from the U.S., Canada, the U.K. and other producers not allied with the cartel, but the meeting ended with a press release that did not mention specific reduction targets and offered only to work together to ensure oil "market stability."
Some producers are pinning their hopes on Pres. Trump, who has been making frequent late-night phone calls to Russia's Pres. Putin, Saudi Arabia's King Salman and other key players in the oil market.
Earlier in the day, Mexican Pres. Lopez Obrador said Trump had promised him the U.S. would cover two-thirds of the production curbs OPEC+ had demanded of Mexico, although cartel officials have not announced any such deal.

《彭博》報導，過去20年來，墨西哥從投行或石油公司買入亞式選擇權（Asian option），這種選擇權相當於保險，讓墨西哥有權力以事先決定好的價格出售石油，代表墨西哥得以享受高油價的獲利，卻在油價崩跌的時候，仍有最低收益的保障。報導指出，這讓墨西哥比其它國家更能抵禦低油價衝擊，如2008年金融海嘯，布蘭特原油（Brent）從每桶近140美元崩跌到45美元左右時，墨西哥仍能在2009年倒賺51億美元，或是2016年油價因沙國價格戰而低至每桶35美元左右時，墨西哥仍賺了27億美元

唔怪得企咁硬
